questions.text: Which of the following diseases are included in the scheme, which has the logo as given below?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option C) CVD, Cancer, Diabetes, Stroke

Explanation:

  • The logo given in the image is of the National Programme for Prevention and Control of Cancer, Diabetes, Cardiovascular Diseases and Stroke (NPCDCS).
  • Under this programme, the included diseases are CVD, Cancer, Diabetes, and Stroke.

The National Programme for Prevention and Control of Cancer, Diabetes, Cardiovascular Diseases and Stroke (NPCDCS) is explicitly described as an integrated program. It combines efforts to address cancer, diabetes, cardiovascular diseases, and stroke, making it the most suitable program with a logo reflecting this integrated approach.

Component

Initiatives

New Initiatives under NPCDCS
  1. Intervention for prevention and control of Rheumatic Heart Disease under NPCDCS and Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram (RBSK).
  2. Integration of AYUSH with NPCDCS.
  3. Integration of RNTCP with NPCDCS to articulate a national strategy for management of TB and diabetes comorbidities in India.

Cancer Component under NPCDCS

Cancer Services under NPCDCS:

  • Providing common diagnostic services, basic surgery, chemotherapy, and palliative care for cancer patients at 100 district hospitals.
  • Supporting each district with chemotherapy drugs for 100 patients, establishing day-care chemotherapy facilities, and providing facilities for laboratory investigations, including mammography.
  • Offering home-based palliative care for chronic and progressive cancer patients in 100 districts.
  • Designating State Cancer Institutes (SCIs) as apex institutions for comprehensive cancer diagnosis, treatment, and care.
  • Strengthening 45 centres as Tertiary Cancer Centres (TCCs) to deliver comprehensive cancer care services.

questions.text: Which organization is not involved in providing funding for India's national TB program?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - UNICEF

  • The World Bank, The Global Fund, and Domestic Budgetary Sources are the main funding sources used to purchase anti-tuberculosis medications, tools like microscopes, and diagnostics like CBNAAT cartridges for this programme.
  • Through funding from DBS and the World Bank, the Central Medical Services Society (CMSS), an independent and autonomous organisation under the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, purchases the medicines and other supplies.
  • The Global Drug Facility, which is run and maintained by the United Nations Office for Project Services, uses The Global Fund.

Sustainable Development Goal (SDG) to Control TB

  • Aim- to eliminate TB by 2030.
  • Target- set by WHO
    • To reduce mortality of TB by 90%. (Option B)
    • To reduce incidence of TB by 80%. (Option D)

Global targets under SDG :

  • To reach 90% of all people with TB.
  • To reach 90% of all key populations (Slum dwellers, prisoners, difficult to reach, occupational exposures-silicosis).
  • To achieve 90% treatment.

End TB

  • Launched by WHO in 2015.
  • Frameline- 2015- 2035
  • Aim- Eliminate TB by 2035. (Option A)
  • Target- 95-90-0
    • Reduce mortality of TB by 95%
    • Reduce incidence of TB by 90%
    • Zero out of pocket expenditure - Government should look after the treatment.

Stop TB

  • It was in alignment with Millennium development goals.
  • Target: To reduce mortality & incidence of TB by 50%. (Option C) And Eliminate TB by 2050.

questions.text: Which antigen is present in the Hepatitis B subunit vaccine?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B) HbsAg

 

Explanation:

 

  • Hepatitis B subunit vaccine contains the surface antigen of the hepatitis B virus (HBV), which is known as HBsAg (Hepatitis B surface antigen). This antigen is a protein component of the viral envelope and is produced using recombinant DNA technology. It is the major antigen responsible for inducing an immune response against HBV.

 

Incorrect Options:

 

HbeAg (Hepatitis B e antigen) (Option A): This antigen is a marker of active viral replication in individuals infected with hepatitis B virus (HBV). It is not a component of the hepatitis B subunit vaccine.

 

HbcAg (Hepatitis B core antigen) (Option C): This antigen is the inner core protein of the hepatitis B virus. It is not included in the hepatitis B subunit vaccine.

 

HBV DNA (Hepatitis B virus DNA) (Option D): HBV DNA is the genetic material of the hepatitis B virus. It is not a component of the hepatitis B subunit vaccine.

questions.text: Which of the following is included in the Pentavalent vaccine?

choices.text: Diphtheria, Pertussis, Tetanus, HBV, Injectable Polio
Diphtheria, Pertussis, Tetanus, Haemophilus influenza B, Pneumococcal vaccine
Diphtheria, Tetanus, HBV, Haemophilus influenza B, Pertussis

questions.solution:
Correct Option: D) Diphtheria, Tetanus, HBV, Haemophilus influenza B, Pertussis

Explanation:

  • The pentavalent vaccine includes the following components:
    • Diphtheria
    • Tetanus
    • HBV (Hepatitis B Virus)
    • Haemophilus influenza B (Hib)
    • Pertussis (Whooping Cough)
  • The pentavalent vaccine combines these five components into a single formulation to provide protection against these diseases.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Diphtheria, Pertussis, Tetanus, HBV, Injectable Polio: This option is incorrect because it includes "Injectable Polio" as one of the components of the pentavalent vaccine.

Option B - Diphtheria, Pertussis, Typhoid, HBV, Hib: This option is incorrect because it includes "Typhoid" as one of the components of the pentavalent vaccine.

Option C - Diphtheria, Pertussis, Tetanus, Haemophilus influenza B, Pneumococcal vaccine: This option is incorrect because it includes the "Pneumococcal vaccine" as one of the components of the pentavalent vaccine.

questions.text: Which vaccine is linked to the risk of intussusception when administered?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) Rotavirus vaccine

Explanation:

  • The administration of the Rotavirus vaccine is associated with a small risk of intussusception.
  • The association between the Rotavirus vaccine and intussusception was first observed with an earlier version of the vaccine called RotaShield, which was withdrawn from the market in 1999.
  • Subsequent studies on newer rotavirus vaccines, such as RotaTeq and Rotarix, have found a small increased risk of intussusception following vaccination.

 

Incorrect Options:

Oral Polio vaccine (Option B): OPV is used to protect against polio and has not been found to have a significant association with intussusception.

Adenovirus vaccine (Option C): Intussusception is not a known side effect or risk associated with the administration of Adenovirus vaccines.

Measles vaccine (Option D): The Measles vaccine is not associated with an increased risk of intussusception.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases is not included in the RBSK screening?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Congenital glaucoma

  • The RBSK (Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram) screening program is a government initiative in India aimed at identifying and providing early intervention for various health conditions in children up to the age of 18 years.
  • The diseases screened under RBSK include conditions like congenital cataract, retinopathy of prematurity (ROP), and Vitamin A deficiency.
  • However, congenital glaucoma is not part of the routine screening under RBSK.

Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram (RBSK):

Aspect

Details

Program

Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram (RBSK)

Launched

2013 under the National Health Mission

Objective

Improve child health through early identification, screening, and management of health conditions among children aged 0 to 18 years

Target Conditions (4Ds)

Defects at Birth: Examples include cleft lip/palate, Down syndrome

Diseases: Examples include rheumatic heart disease

Deficiencies: Examples include anemia, Vitamin A deficiency

Developmental Delays including Disabilities

Screening Teams

Mobile health teams comprising a medical officer, staff nurse, and pharmacist

Screening Locations

Schools, Anganwadi centers, and homes

Referral System

District Early Intervention Centers (DEICs) for further management

Significance

Improves early detection and management of child health issues, reducing morbidity and enhancing quality of life

Congenital cataract (Option A): This condition is included in the RBSK screening, as it is an important cause of preventable blindness in children.

Retinopathy of Prematurity (ROP) (Option C): ROP is included in the screening, as it is a major cause of visual impairment in premature infants.

Vitamin A deficiency (Option D): This is also part of the RBSK screening, as it can lead to blindness and other health complications.

questions.text: What does JSSK stand for?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Janani Shishu Suraksha Karyakram:

  • The Janani Shishu Suraksha Karyakram (JSSK) is a scheme launched by the Government of India to provide free and cashless healthcare services to pregnant women, mothers, and newborns. The program aims to reduce maternal and infant mortality rates by ensuring that all pregnant women and newborns have access to essential healthcare services without financial constraints.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C, and D are incorrect as given above.

questions.text: Which statement accurately describes the Nikshay Poshan Yojana program?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Rs 500 is given per month

Explanation:

  • The Nikshay Poshan Yojana is a government initiative launched by the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare to provide nutritional support to individuals undergoing treatment for Tuberculosis (TB). The program aims to improve the nutritional status of TB patients, as proper nutrition is essential for effective treatment and recovery.
  • Under this scheme:
    • Rs 500 is provided monthly to TB patients as nutritional support to help them adhere to their treatment and improve overall health.

 

Rs 500 is given per week (Option A): This is incorrect because the scheme provides Rs 500 per month, not weekly.

Mid-day meals are given (Option C): This is not part of the Nikshay Poshan Yojana. The program provides financial support for nutrition, but not direct meal distribution.

Dietary advice is given (Option D): While nutrition is a component, the primary focus of the scheme is financial support for food, not direct dietary counseling.

questions.text: As a medical officer at a Primary Health Center (PHC), what would be your recommendation for mass prophylaxis/treatment of anemia?

choices.text: FeS04 + Vit C + Folate + Vit B12

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) FeSO4 + Vit C + Folate + Vit B12

Explanation:

As a medical officer at a Primary Health Center (PHC), for mass prophylaxis or treatment of anemia, the most common approach would include a combination of iron (to treat iron deficiency anemia), along with vitamin C (to enhance iron absorption), folate (for folate deficiency), and vitamin B12 (for vitamin B12 deficiency). This combination is effective for treating nutritional anemia and anemia due to multiple deficiencies in populations, particularly in rural or underserved areas.

  • FeSO4 (Ferrous sulfate) is a commonly used form of oral iron.
  • Vitamin C enhances the absorption of iron.
  • Folate and Vitamin B12 address deficiencies that can contribute to anemia, particularly megaloblastic anemia

 

Iron (III) hydroxide polymaltose (Option B): This is an oral iron preparation, but it's typically used when iron sulfate is not tolerated due to gastrointestinal side effects. However, it may not be the first choice for mass prophylaxis.

Ferrous fumarate (Option C): Another form of oral iron, but the inclusion of vitamins C, B12, and folate in Option A makes it a more comprehensive approach.

Inj. iron sucrose (Option D): This is an injectable iron preparation used for patients who cannot tolerate oral iron or have severe iron deficiency anemia. However, it is not typically used for mass prophylaxis at the PHC level due to its cost and the need for trained personnel to administer injections.

questions.text: The World Health Organization (WHO) has defined blindness as a condition where the level of visual acuity is below
questions.solution:
Correct Answer - Option B : 3/60

Explanation:

  • WHO (World Health Organization) defines blindness as visual acuity less than 3/60. It indicates severe impairment of vision, where the person can only see at a distance of 3 meters or less what a person with normal vision can see clearly at 60 meters.

WHO Classification of Visual Impairment
  • The World Health Organization (WHO) defines blindness as "visual acuity of less than 3/60 (Snellen) or its equivalent".
  • The International Classification of Disease 11 (2018) classifies vision impairment into distance and near-presenting vision impairment

Classification

Visual Acuity

Mild Distance Vision Impairment

Presenting visual acuity worse than 6/12

Moderate Distance Vision Impairment

Presenting visual acuity worse than 6/18 (Option D ruled out)

Severe Distance Vision Impairment

Presenting visual acuity worse than 6/60 (Option A ruled out)

Blindness

Presenting visual acuity worse than 3/60 (Option B)

Near Vision Impairment

Presenting near vision acuity worse than N6 or M0.8 at 40 cm with existing correction (Option C ruled out)

questions.text: A researcher who was studying on plasmodium species decided to visit the malaria-endemic place in Odisha after 2 days to do his clinical study for 5 weeks. Which of the following drugs need to be taken as prophylaxis before visiting the malaria-endemic place?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option C- Doxycycline

Explanation:

  • The most appropriate drug for short-term malaria prophylaxis is Doxycycline 100mg daily.

Chemoprophylaxis of malaria:

 

Short-term prophylaxis

Long-term prophylaxis

Duration of Rx

< 6 weeks

> 6 weeks

DOC

Doxycycline 100 mg daily (Option C)

Mefloquine 250 mg weekly (Option B ruled out)

Prophylaxis period

Before travel

1-2 days

2-3 weeks

After travel

4 weeks

4 weeks

Contraindications of mefloquine:

  • History of convulsions.

Other drugs for short-term prophylaxis:

Artesunate (Option A): It is typically used to treat malaria. This option is incorrect.

questions.text: What is the quickest method for laboratory diagnosis of pulmonary tuberculosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: Option A) CB-NAAT

 

Explanation:

CB-NAAT is a molecular diagnostic test that can detect the genetic material (DNA) of Mycobacterium tuberculosis, the bacterium that causes TB. It is a highly sensitive and specific test that can provide rapid results.

Diagnostic Modality

Description

Usage

Sputum Smear Microscopy (Option B ruled out)

Microscopic examination of sputum samples to detect acid-fast bacilli (AFB).

Used for initial screening and diagnosis, especially in resource-limited settings.

Chest X-ray

Imaging done to identify abnormalities suggestive of TB.

Used to support diagnosis when clinical suspicion is high; not definitive for TB diagnosis.

TruNAAT/CBNAAT (Option A)

Molecular tests that detect Mycobacterial DNA and rifampicin resistance.

Recommended for initial diagnosis due to high sensitivity and specificity; rapid results.

Line Probe Assay (LPA)

Molecular test to detect specific genetic mutations associated with drug resistance (e.g., rifampicin, isoniazid).

Used for detecting drug resistance in confirmed TB cases, not for initial diagnosis.

Tuberculin Skin Test (TST)

A skin test to measure immune response to injected tuberculin protein.

Primarily used for screening latent TB infection; not specific for active TB diagnosis.

Interferon-Gamma Release Assays (IGRAs)

Blood cytokine analysis test that measures immune response to TB antigens.

Used for detecting latent TB infection

Sputum Culture (Option C ruled out)

 

Growing Mycobacteria from sputum samples to confirm TB and test for drug susceptibility.

Gold standard for TB diagnosis; takes several weeks to obtain results.

Drug Susceptibility Testing (DST)

Testing TB bacteria from patient samples to determine resistance to TB drugs.

Used to guide treatment by identifying drug-resistant strains in confirmed TB cases.

Radiometric BACTEC method (Option D): It offers faster detection compared to conventional culture methods but still requires several weeks to obtain results. This option is incorrect.

questions.text: As a medical officer posted in rural service, you have been asked to supervise the various preventive measures being taken in your region against malaria. According to the program whose logo is shown below, you would be correct to advise all of the following except:

choices.text: Two rounds of spraying with DDT should be done to provide protection during the entire transmission season.
Long lasting insecticide nest (LLIN) should be provided in areas with annual parasite Index 25.
Indoor residual sprays are not suitable for vector control in rural areas.
In case of DDT resistance, 3 rounds of spraying with Malathion should be done to provide protection during the entire transmission season.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer- Option C: Indoor residual sprays are not suitable for vector control in rural areas.

Explanation:

  • This image shows the National Vector-Born Disease Control Program (NVBDCP).
  • Indoor residual spraying (IRS) is considered an effective vector control measure, including in rural areas.
  • IRS involves spraying insecticides on the interior walls of houses to kill mosquitoes and reduce their population. It is an important component of integrated malaria control programs.

National vector-borne disease control program (NVBDCP):

  • Launched: 2002.
  • Includes all vector-borne diseases:

Vector

Disease

Anopheles
  • Malaria

Aedes
  • Dengue & chikungunya

Culex
  • Japanese encephalitis: Culex quinquefasciatus/ Culex fatigans
  • Filariasis: Culex tritaeniorhynchus, Culex vishnui

Sandfly
  • Kala-azar

Indoor residual spray (IRS):

  • Chemicals used:
    • DDT 50% WP: Insecticide of choice
    • Malathion 25%
    • Synthetic pyrethroids: Deltamethrin and Cyfluthrin
  • IRS with insecticides when API >2:

2 rounds of DDT (1gm/m2) at a 6-week interval during the transmission season (Option A ruled out)

↓

If refractory:

ADD malathion, 3 rounds of Malathion (2gm/m2) at 6-week intervals. (Option D ruled out)

↓

If still refractory:

ADD 2 rounds of a synthetic pyrethroid (0.25gm/m2) at 6-week intervals.

Note: Long-lasting insecticidal nets (LLIN) covers the population living in areas where API > 5.

Long-Lasting Insecticidal Nets (LLINs) are mosquito nets treated with insecticides that are designed to retain their effectiveness for an extended period, typically up to 3 years, even after repeated washing. They are a critical tool in NVBDCP to fight against mosquito-borne diseases. (Option B ruled out)

Purpose:

  • Dual action provides a physical barrier against mosquito bites while also delivering insecticidal action.

Material and Mesh Size:

  • Made from polyester or polyethene.
  • Mesh size: around 156 holes per square inch.

questions.text: Which of the following populations is not included in the HIV sentinel surveillance?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - STD clinic attendees.

  • HIV Sentinel Surveillance (HSS) is designed to track the trends of HIV prevalence in different population groups.
  • However, STD clinic attendees are not specifically included in the sentinel surveillance system in most cases.
  • This is because these individuals are already considered a part of the high-risk population, and their data may overlap with other more defined high-risk groups, such as female sex workers and men who have sex with men.

HIV Sentinel Surveillance (HSS):

Category

Details

Objective

Monitor trends in HIV prevalence, guide public health interventions, and identify high-risk populations.

Sentinel Sites

Specific locations for surveillance, including antenatal clinics, STD clinics, and high-risk community settings.

Populations Included

Antenatal Women: To estimate HIV prevalence in the general population.

High-Risk Groups: Female sex workers (FSWs), men who have sex with men (MSM), injecting drug users (IDUs).

Bridge Populations: Truck drivers, single male migrants.

Data Collected

HIV Prevalence: Percentage of individuals in the group who are HIV-positive.

Demographic Information: Age, gender, occupation, etc.

Risk Behavior: Sexual behavior, drug use, and other HIV transmission risk factors.

Key Features

Regular blood sample collection.

HIV testing conducted in sentinel sites.

Exclusions

STD clinic attendees may not be included as their data overlaps with other high-risk groups.

Importance

Tracks HIV trends over time.

Guides the allocation of resources.

Helps design targeted prevention programs for at-risk populations.

Single male migrants (Option A): They are often at higher risk due to mobility and exposure to multiple sexual partners.

Truck drivers (Option B): A high-risk group due to frequent travel and potential for high-risk sexual behavior.

Antenatal women (Option D): Provide important data on the general population and mother-to-child transmission.

choices.text: Urban health equity assessment and response tool

Urban health evaluation assessment and response technique

questions.text: Which of the following is true for DOTS?

choices.text: Every patient is given the same treatment
Streptomycin is given to all the patients

questions.solution:
Correct Option A) Treatment under supervision

Explanation:

  • DOTS is a globally recommended strategy for the treatment of tuberculosis (TB). One of the key principles of DOTS is that treatment is administered under direct supervision by a healthcare provider or trained observer.
  • This ensures that patients adhere to the prescribed treatment regimen and complete the full course of treatment, which is essential for successful TB treatment and prevention of drug resistance.

 

99DOTS:

  • A cost-effective method to monitor and improve adherence to TB medication.
  • Anti-TB blister packs are wrapped in envelopes with hidden toll free phone numbers revealed only when doses are dispensed.
  • Patients make a call to the hidden number after taking their medication, confirming dose intake.

questions.text: A' Bacteriologically Confirmed Case' in TB is defined as:
questions.solution:
Correct Option B) Sputum positive

Explanation:

  • A "sputum positive" case in TB refers to a person who has been diagnosed with TB based on the presence of Mycobacterium tuberculosis (the bacteria that causes TB) in their sputum sample.
  • A positive sputum test confirms the presence of TB bacteria, making it an important diagnostic criterion for identifying TB cases.

 

The new NTEP changes in terminologies are as follows:-

Category

Description

Criteria/Features

Presumptive TB Case

 

Used in place of TB suspect. Individuals showing symptoms suggestive of TB but not yet confirmed.

-Cough, Fever, Night sweats +- Weight loss > 2 weeks (Option D ruled out)

Clinically Diagnosed TB Case

 

Sputum negative but with high clinical suspicion of TB. Used in place of Sputum negative TB case.

-Persistent symptoms despite negative sputum smear

- High clinical suspicion based on symptoms, radiological and histological features (Option A ruled out)

Bacteriologically Confirmed TB Case (Option B)

 

Biological specimen is positive for sputum AFB and/or CBNAAT. Used in place of Sputum positive TB case.

- Positive sputum smear for AFB

- Positive CBNAAT test confirming the presence of TB bacteria

questions.text: What type of blindness does the individual have if their right eye has a visual acuity of 6/60 and their left eye has a visual acuity of 3/60?
questions.solution:
Correct option:

Option C: Low vision

  • Low vision refers to a significant visual impairment that cannot be fully corrected with glasses, contact lenses, medication, or surgery.
  • Individuals with low vision have visual acuity below normal levels but still have some remaining functional vision.
  • In the given scenario, the person's visual acuity is 6/60 in the right eye and 3/60 in the left eye, indicating a severe visual impairment.

Incorrect Options

Option A: Manifest blindness- Vision 3/60 or just perception of light. It does not accurately describe the person's condition.

Option B: Social blindness- Vision 3/60 or Diniution of the field of vision to 10 degrees. It does not accurately describe the person's condition.

Option D: Absence of blindness- This option is incorrect because the person clearly has a visual impairment. The visual acuity measurements indicate a significant reduction in vision.

questions.text: According to the World Health Organization (WHO), which of the following best defines blindness?

choices.text: Best corrected visual acuity <6/60 in the better eye
Best corrected visual acuity <3/60 in the better eye
Uncorrected visual acuity <6/60 in any eye
Uncorrected visual acuity <3/60 in any eye

questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Best corrected visual acuity <3/60 in the better eye:

Explanation:

  • The World Health Organization (WHO) defines blindness as having a best corrected visual acuity of less than 3/60 in the better eye

 

WHO Classification of Visual Impairment

The World Health Organization (WHO) defines blindness as "visual acuity of less than 3/60 (Snellen) or its equivalent". (Option B)

The International Classification of Disease 11 (2018) classifies vision impairment into distance and near-presenting vision impairment

Classification

Visual Acuity

Mild Distance Vision Impairment

Presenting visual acuity worse than 6/12

Moderate Distance Vision Impairment

Presenting visual acuity worse than 6/18

Severe Distance Vision Impairment

Presenting visual acuity worse than 6/60

Blindness

Presenting visual acuity worse than 3/60

Near Vision Impairment

Presenting near vision acuity worse than N6 or M0.8 at 40 cm with existing correction

 

NPCB Classification of Visual Impairment

The National Programme for Control of Blindness (NPCB) in India defines blindness as "visual acuity of <3/60 in a better eye with best possible correction" and central visual field <10 degrees. The NPCB further categorizes visual impairment as:

Classification

Visual Acuity

Visual Impairment

Visual acuity of less than 6/18 in the better eye with available correction

Low Vision

Visual acuity of less than 6/18 to 6/60

Economic Blindness

Visual acuity of less than 6/60 to 3/60

Social Blindness

Visual acuity of less than 3/60 to 1/60

Manifest Blindness

Visual acuity of less than 1/60 to the perception of light

Absolute Blindness

No perception of light

questions.text: According to recent NACO guidelines, which of the following groups is no longer classified as a high-risk group (HRG) for HIV transmission?

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Truck drivers

Sentinel Surveillance for HIV:

HIV Sentinel Surveillance

HIV sentinel surveillance tracks missing cases and monitors HIV infection trends in specific groups and regions to understand epidemic dynamics and guide public health interventions.

Objectives
  • Monitor HIV infection trends & emerging pockets of HIV infection.
  • Estimate HIV prevalence in general population as well as high-risk groups and burden in the country and high-risk groups across states.
  • Provide data for program evaluation and improvement.

Key Features
  • Focus on High-Risk Groups: Commercial sex workers (CSW), men who have sex with men (MSM), injecting drug users, and transgender individuals. (Option A, B, D ruled out)
  • Antenatal Women as Proxies: Includes data from antenatal women to estimate HIV prevalence in the general population.

Key Uses
  • Resource Allocation: Helps direct resources and interventions to the most affected areas and populations.
  • Program Evaluation: Tracks trends to evaluate the effectiveness of HIV/AIDS control programs.
  • Early Warning System: Acts as an early warning for emerging outbreaks or changes in transmission patterns.

Frequency and Timing

Conducted biennially, with the most recent surveillance in India done in 2021

questions.text: What is the name of the technical platform developed under India’s National Tele Mental Health Programme (NTMHP) to deliver mental healthcare services through a multi-tiered system via telephone, digital platforms, and online portals?

Tele-MANAS:

  • Objective:

    • Reduce stigma and bridge the treatment gap for mental illnesses.
  • Structure:
    • Tier 1: State Tele-MANAS cells with trained counsellors and mental health professionals answering calls via a toll-free helpline.
    • Tier 2: District-level mental health facilities for in-person follow-up and advanced care.

    • Toll-free 24×7 helpline.

NIKSHAY (Option A): Web-enabled application for TB surveillance, monitoring, and patient management under the National TB Elimination Programme.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with difficulty in walking, bowing of legs, is underweight, and has minimal sun exposure. Which of the following government schemes addresses nutritional deficiencies in children under 6 years of age?

questions.text: The biological method for Mosquito Larva control is done by?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: C) Gambusia fish

Explanation:

  • Gambusia fish are voracious feeders and consume mosquito larvae, thus helping to reduce the mosquito population in water bodies where they are introduced. They are particularly effective in controlling mosquito larvae in stagnant or slow-moving water bodies like ponds, ditches, and water tanks.
  • This method of biological control is environmentally friendly and sustainable. Additionally, Gambusia fish are easy to rear and maintain, making them a practical and cost-effective solution for mosquito larva control in certain habitats.

Environmental measures

Chemical control

Biological control

Yield permanent results and source reduction.

  • Intermittent irrigation.

questions.text: The Anemia Mukt Bharat program aims to address anemia across India through targeted interventions. Which statement accurately describes its administration of Iron and Folic Acid (IFA) supplementation?

choices.text: IFA is provided during the 2nd trimester of pregnancy and continues during lactation for up to 6 months
IFA supplementation is administered solely during pregnancy
A 100-day course of IFA supplementation is sufficient
Administering IFA during the 1st trimester is adequate.

questions.solution:
Correct Option A- IFA is provided during the 2nd trimester of pregnancy and continues during lactation for up to 6 months

 

  • The Anemia Mukt Bharat program includes comprehensive IFA supplementation that begins during the 2nd trimester of pregnancy and continues through lactation for up to 6 months.
  • Weekly Iron Folic Acid Supplementation:
    • 5-9 year children: Weekly 1 IFA - 45 mg. of Fe + 400 mcg. of folic acid, sugar coated - pink color. Biannual deworming with one tablet of Albendazole tablet 400 mg done during the National Deworming days once in 6 months (10 of Aug and 10 of Feb of every year)
    • Adolescent boys and girls - weekly 1 IFA - containing 100 mg Fe and 500 mcg of folic acid and biannual deworming with 1 tablet of 400 mg Albendazole.
    • Pregnant women: starts in 2nd trimester of pregnancy and continues through lactation for up to 6 months.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C, and D are incorrect as IFA is provided during the 2nd trimester of pregnancy and continues during lactation for up to 6 months.

questions.text: What is the WHO definition of blindness?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B- 3/60

Explanation:

  • The World Health Organization (WHO) defines blindness as a visual acuity of less than 3/60 in the better eye with the best possible correction.

Distance vision impairment (WHO):

  • Mild – visual acuity worse than 6/12
  • Moderate – visual acuity worse than 6/18 (Option C)
  • Severe – visual acuity worse than 6/60 (Option A)
  • Blindness – visual acuity worse than 3/60 (Option B)

1/60 (Option D): 1/60 is not the specific cut-off point defined by the WHO for blindness.

questions.text: Which of the following is correct regarding Ayushman Bharat scheme?

choices.text: Rs 5 lakh/per family per year is given
Rs 10 lakh/per family per year is given
Rs 6 lakh/per family per year is given
Rs 2 lakh/per family per year is given

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Rs 5 lakh/per family per year is given:

  • Ayushman Bharat, also known as the Pradhan Mantri Jan Arogya Yojana (PMJAY), is a health insurance scheme launched by the Government of India. The scheme aims to provide financial protection to economically vulnerable families by offering health insurance coverage for secondary and tertiary care hospitalization.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Rs 10 lakh/per family per year: It is not the correct amount provided by the Ayushman Bharat scheme. The correct amount is Rs 5 lakh.

Option C - Rs 6 lakh/per family per year: It is not the correct amount provided by the Ayushman Bharat scheme. The correct amount is Rs 5 lakh.

Option D - Rs 2 lakh/per family per year: It is not the correct amount provided by the Ayushman Bharat scheme. The correct amount is Rs 5 lakh.

questions.text: In the Ayushman Bharat scheme, what is the annual health insurance coverage offered to a qualifying family?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - 5 lakhs per family per year:

  • In the Ayushman Bharat scheme, also known as Pradhan Mantri Jan Arogya Yojana (PMJAY), the health insurance package provided for an eligible family is 5 lakhs per family per year.
  • This means that eligible families can avail medical treatment and hospitalization services up to a maximum coverage of 5 lakhs (Indian Rupees) per year.

Pradhan Mantri Jan Arogya Yojana.

  • Launched in 2018
  • Aim: To achieve Universal Health Coverage in India.
  • It is a flexible scheme.
    • It is not rigid or mandatory for all states to follow.
    • The States can opt to choose.
  • Private Hospitals that have up to 10 beds can provide services under Ayushman Bharat Scheme.
  • It comes under the National Health Protection Scheme Modi Care.
  • Provides insurance coverage - 5 lakh per family, per year.
  • There is no restriction on number of family members.

questions.text: According to the guidelines of the National Tuberculosis Elimination Program (NTEP), what would be the criteria to designate a district as a high priority district based on the prevalence of HIV TB?
questions.solution: According to the guidelines of the National Tuberculosis Elimination Program (NTEP), a district is designated as a high-priority district based on the prevalence of HIV among tuberculosis (TB) patients. Specifically, if more than 10% of TB patients are found to be HIV-positive, the district is categorized as a high-priority area for intensified TB-HIV collaborative activities.

questions.text: As part of the Anemia Mukt Bharat program, pregnant women with mild to moderate anemia who are less than 34 weeks pregnant are managed with the following treatment approach:

choices.text: 2 iron and folic acid (IFA) tablets OD
IV iron sucrose for noncompliance with oral tablets
2 iron and folic acid tablets OD + IV iron sucrose

questions.solution:
As part of the Anemia Mukt Bharat program, pregnant women with mild to moderate anemia who are less than 34 weeks pregnant are generally managed with oral iron and folic acid (IFA) tablets. The typical treatment involves 2 IFA tablets OD (once a day).

  • IV iron sucrose is usually considered for noncompliant patients who are unable to take oral supplements effectively or when oral supplementation does not improve the condition, but it is not the first-line treatment in cases of mild to moderate anemia.
  • IM ferric carboxy maltose (FCM) is also an alternative but is typically reserved for more severe cases of anemia or in cases where intravenous iron is needed.

Therefore, for mild to moderate anemia in pregnant women less than 34 weeks, oral IFA tablets are the standard first-line treatment.

The 6x6x6 strategy is related to anemia mukt Bharat. It stands for 6 beneficiaries, 6 interventions, and 6 institutional mechanisms.

6 INTERVENTIONS

6 STRATEGIES
  • Prophylactic iron-folic acid supplementation.
  • Deworming.
  • Intensified year-round behaviour change communication campaign (solid body, smart mind), including ensured delayed cord clamping.
  • Testing of anaemia using digital methods and point-of-care treatment.
  • Mandatory provision of iron folic acid fortified foods in public health programmes.
  • Addressing non-nutritional causes of anaemia in endemic pockets with a special focus on malaria, hemoglobinopathies, and fluorosis.
  • National Anaemia Mukt Bharat Unit.
  • Intra-ministerial coordination.
  • Strengthening supply chain and logistics.
  • Convergence with other ministries.
  • National Centre of Excellence and Advanced Research on Anaemia Control.
  • Anaemia Mukt Bharat dashboard and digital portal- One-stop shop for anaemia.

6 BENEFICIARIES
  • Children, 6-59 months of age (Bi-weekly Administer 1 ml of Iron and Folic Acid syrup containing 20 mg elemental iron and 100 mcg folic acid per dose)
  • Children, 5-9 years of age- pink tablets (Weekly administer one sugar-coated pink tablet of Iron and Folic Acid containing 45 mg elemental iron and 400 mcg folic acid)
  • Adolescent girls & boys (10-19 years of age)- blue tablets (Weekly administer one sugar-coated blue tablet of Iron and Folic Acid containing 60 mg elemental iron and 500 mcg folic acid)
  • Women of reproductive age group (20-24 years of age).(Weekly, administer one sugar-coated red tablet of Iron and Folic Acid containing 60 mg elemental iron and 500 mcg folic acid)
  • Pregnant women- Red tablets (180 tablets)Daily, 1 Iron and Folic Acid tablet should be taken starting from the fourth month of pregnancy (second trimester) and continued throughout the pregnancy (for at least 180 days). Each tablet contains 60 mg elemental iron and 500 mcg folic acid, is sugar-coated, and red in color.
  • Lactating mothers (of 0-6 months child)- Red tablets .The tablet should also be continued for 180 days post-partum. Each tablet contains 60 mg elemental iron and 500 mcg folic acid, is sugar-coated, and red in color.

questions.text: School health program is under:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) PHC

Explanation:

  • The School Health Program in India is typically managed and implemented under Primary Health Centres (PHCs).
  • These centers provide basic healthcare services to communities, including children in schools, through regular health check-ups, immunizations, and health education.
  • The PHCs serve as the main hub for delivering health services to the school-aged population.

 

CHC (Option B): is incorrect because Community Health Centres (CHCs) focus on more specialized and advanced healthcare services than PHCs. They are not the primary location for managing the School Health Program.

DH (Option C): is incorrect because District Hospitals (DH) focus on providing specialized healthcare and emergency services rather than delivering primary health services in schools.

Health and Wellness Centres (Option D): While Health and Wellness Centres are part of the National Health Mission and offer comprehensive healthcare services, the School Health Program is more closely associated with PHCs for primary healthcare services in the school setting.

questions.text: In the context of a national public health initiative aimed at addressing anemia, which of the following programs follows the "6x6x6 strategy"?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Anemia Mukt Bharat

Explanation:

The Anemia Mukt Bharat (AMB) program, launched by the Government of India, aims to reduce anemia among women, children, and adolescents. The "6x6x6 strategy" refers to a set of actions designed to address anemia, focusing on:

  • 6 target age groups (children aged 6-59 months, adolescent girls, pregnant women, lactating mothers, women of reproductive age, and men)
  • 6 interventions (Iron and Folic Acid supplementation, deworming, malaria control, nutrition improvement, managing hemorrhage during childbirth, and controlling hookworm)
  • 6 delivery platforms (school-based programs, anganwadis, health centers, etc.)

 

Poshan Abhiyan (Option B): is incorrect because the Poshan Abhiyan (National Nutrition Mission) focuses on improving the nutritional status of children, pregnant women, and lactating mothers but does not specifically follow the "6x6x6 strategy" related to anemia.

Kishori Shakti Yojana (Option C): is incorrect because the Kishori Shakti Yojana focuses on the empowerment of adolescent girls, providing them with life skills training, but it does not follow the "6x6x6 strategy" for addressing anemia.

None of these (Option D): is incorrect because Anemia Mukt Bharat (Option A) clearly follows the "6x6x6 strategy" for anemia control.

questions.text: Which government program aims to provide health checkups and services for children aged 0-18, including a focus on those not attending school?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakaram

Explanation:

  • The Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakaram (RBSK) is a government initiative aimed at providing health checkups and services to children aged 0-18 years, including those who are not attending school. The program focuses on identifying and addressing health issues, such as congenital abnormalities, disabilities, and malnutrition, ensuring early intervention and appropriate treatment.

 

Janani Suraksha Yojna (Option B): is incorrect because Janani Suraksha Yojna primarily focuses on providing safe motherhood, promoting institutional deliveries, and reducing maternal and neonatal mortality, rather than addressing the health needs of children aged 0-18 years.

Navjaat Shishu Suraksha Karyakaram (Option C): is incorrect because Navjaat Shishu Suraksha Karyakaram focuses on ensuring newborn survival by providing immediate care at the time of birth and focusing on newborn health rather than a comprehensive child health program for the 0-18 age group.

Mid Day Meal Program (Option D): is incorrect because the Mid Day Meal Program focuses on providing nutritious meals to children in schools, particularly to promote enrollment and retention, and does not cover comprehensive health checkups and services for children outside of school.

questions.text: A 10-year-old school-going girl came for a health checkup. Her Hb is 9 g/dL. Which of the following government programs is likely to provide significant benefit to her health?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram (RBSK)

Explanation:

  • RBSK is a comprehensive program under the National Health Mission that focuses on early identification and intervention for children aged 0-18 years, targeting deficiencies such as anemia, developmental delays, and diseases. It supports the health and well-being of school-going children like the one described.

Janani Suraksha Yojana (Option B): is incorrect because this scheme focuses on promoting institutional deliveries and maternal health benefits rather than addressing child health and anemia in school-going children.

Pradhan Mantri Matru Vandana Yojana (Option C): is incorrect because it primarily provides financial support to pregnant and lactating mothers for better nutrition and postnatal care, not directly targeting school children.

Navjat Shishu Karyakram Yojana (Option D): is incorrect because it emphasizes newborn care and resuscitation in healthcare settings, not for health checkups of school-going children.

questions.text: What is the CD4 cut off for initiating Antiretroviral Therapy (ART) in the treatment of AIDS?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - No cut-off:

  • The treatment of AIDS, or HIV infection, with Antiretroviral Therapy (ART) is not solely based on a specific CD4 cell count cut-off. The decision to start ART depends on various factors, including clinical symptoms, CD4 count, viral load, and the individual's overall health.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - 200: This CD4 cut-off was previously used, but current guidelines recommend treatment regardless of CD4 count.

Option B - 350: This CD4 cut-off was also previously used, but current guidelines recommend treatment regardless of CD4 count.

Option C - 500: This CD4 cut-off was previously used, but current guidelines recommend treatment regardless of CD4 count.

questions.text: A baby presents for a routine examination in the outpatient department. A growth chart is utilized to record the baby's weight, which falls within the 85th - 95th percentile range. What is the present condition of the child?

choices.text: Interpretation cannot be made without BMI

questions.solution:
Answer Option C - Overweight:

  • Growth charts are used to monitor a child's growth and development over time. These charts provide a range of values called percentiles, which indicate how a child's measurements compare to those of other children of the same age and sex. The 85th-95th percentile range is considered overweight, indicating that the child is heavier than 85-95% of children of the same age and sex.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Obesity: While being overweight is a risk factor for obesity, it is not the same as obesity.

Option B - SAM: Severe acute malnutrition (SAM) is typically diagnosed based on clinical criteria, including a low weight-for-height ratio and nutritional edema.

Option D - Interpretation cannot be made without BMI: This option is irrelavent. As Body mass index (BMI) better indicates body fat percentage than growth charts alone.

questions.text: Which of the following healthcare providers is not working at the village level?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - ANM:

  • ANM (Auxiliary Nurse Midwife) is a healthcare provider works at the sub-centre level to provide basic healthcare services to the community.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Option B -  AWW: AWW (Anganwadi Worker) is a community-level healthcare worker under the Integrated Child Development Services (ICDS) Scheme.

  • Option C - TBA: TBA (Traditional Birth Attendant) is a community-level healthcare provider who provides basic maternal healthcare services and attends to normal deliveries. 

  • Option D - ASHA: ASHA (Accredited Social Health Activist) is a community-level healthcare provider who works under the National Health Mission (NHM) to provide basic healthcare services.

questions.text: Under which program does the improvement of labor room quality fall in?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - LaQshya:

  • LaQshya is a program for the improvement of the quality of labor rooms in healthcare facilities. It is an initiative of the Government of India that aims to enhance the safety and quality of care provided during childbirth. The program focuses on ensuring respectful maternity care, infection prevention and control, effective communication, and skilled birth attendance.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Ayushman Bharat: Ayushman Bharat is a national health protection scheme “in India that aims to provide financial protection and access to quality healthcare to vulnerable population” with “that” focuses on health insurance coverage and primary healthcare services but does not specifically address the improvement of labor room quality.

Option C - Janani Shishu Suraksha Karyakram: Janani Shishu Suraksha Karyakram is a government program that promotes safe delivery and postnatal care, it does not specifically address the improvement of labor room quality.

Option D - Pradhan Mantri Surakshit Matritva Abhiyan: Pradhan Mantri Surakshit Matritva Abhiyan focuses on ensuring comprehensive and quality antenatal check-ups but does not specifically focus on improving labor room quality.

questions.text: Which group is excluded from targeted interventions, a specific set of services and interventions provided to individuals in the population who are at high risk of or have reported high risk of HIV?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Doctors and nursing professionals: 

  • Targeted intervention refers to a specific package of interventions and services designed to reach and address the needs of populations at high risk of HIV or those who have reported a high risk of HIV. Doctors and nurses are not high-risk group but suffer accidental injuries.

 

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Migrant labourers: Migrant labourers, who often move across regions or countries for work, are considered a high-risk group due to factors such as mobility, separation from families, and engagement in risky behaviors.

Option B - Street children: Street children, who may lack stable housing and support systems, are vulnerable to various health risks, including HIV infection.

Option C - Long-distance truckers: Long-distance truckers, who frequently travel across different regions or countries as part of their occupation, are at increased risk of HIV.

questions.text:
In a rural village, a government school conducted a comprehensive health check-up for all its students.

According to Vision 2020, which of the following centre will the teacher refer school children to in order to check their visual acuity?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D -Vision centre:

  • Under the Vision 2020 initiative, which aims to eliminate avoidable blindness, one of the strategies is to provide accessible eye care services. Vision centers are established to provide primary eye care, including vision testing and provision of eyeglasses, in areas where access to eye care is limited. Therefore, the teacher would refer school children to a vision center to check their visual acuity.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Service center: The term "service center" is general and does not specifically relate to eye care or vision testing.

Option B - Training center: Training centers are focused on providing education and training rather than direct provision of eye care services.

Option C - Center for excellence: Centers of excellence generally refer to specialized institutions that excel in a specific field. While they may provide advanced eye care services, they are not typically involved in routine vision testing in schools.

questions.text: Peripheral blood smear sample for malaria is done by?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Laboratory technician:

  • A peripheral blood smear sample for malaria is typically obtained by a laboratory technician. These technicians are trained and skilled in collecting blood samples and preparing blood smears for microscopic examination to detect the presence of malaria parasites.

 

Incorrect Options: 

  • Option A, B & C  are not typically responsible for obtaining peripheral blood smear samples for malaria.

questions.text: Ujjawala scheme is for prevention of?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Child trafficking:

  • The Ujjawala scheme is a government initiative aimed at preventing and combating human trafficking for commercial sexual exploitation. It focuses on rescuing and rehabilitating victims of trafficking, providing them with support services, and raising awareness about the issue.

 

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Child abuse: While the Ujjawala scheme indirectly addresses the prevention of child abuse through its efforts to combat child trafficking, it specifically focuses on trafficking-related issues.

Option C - Child labour: The Ujjawala scheme primarily targets child trafficking rather than child labor.

Option D - Child marriage: Child marriage is not the main focus of the Ujjawala scheme; it primarily addresses human trafficking for commercial sexual exploitation.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male truck driver visited to the clinic with fever, skin rash, swollen glands and fatigue. The physician referred him to suraksha clinic. Which among the following is included in provision of services at Suraksha Clinic?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - RTI/ STI services:

  • The Suraksha Clinic is a healthcare facility that provides services related to reproductive and sexual health. RTI (Reproductive Tract Infection) and STI (Sexually Transmitted Infection) services are included in the range of services offered at the Suraksha Clinic.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Immunization services: Suraksha Clinic primarily focuses on reproductive and sexual health services, and immunization services are not typically provided in this context.

Option B - Blood transfusion safety services: Suraksha Clinic does not specifically provide blood transfusion safety services.

Option D - Diarrhea control services: Diarrhea control services are not typically part of the services offered at the Suraksha Clinic.

questions.text: The proposal to control malaria in towns named as Urban Malaria Scheme. According to Urban Malaria Scheme, Which of the following is not true?

choices.text: Scheme is not based on blood examination
Towns having a population more than 10,000

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Slide positivity rate more than 10%:

  • The Urban Malaria Scheme aims to control malaria in towns and cities. One of the criteria for implementing the scheme is a slide positivity rate (SPR) of more than 5% but less than or equal to 10%. Therefore, the statement "Slide positivity rate more than 10%" is not true.

 

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - SPR between 5% and 10%: This range is a valid criterion for implementing the Urban Malaria Scheme.

Option C - Scheme is not based on blood examination : The scheme is not based on the blood examination slide rate but on the slide positivity rate.

Option D - Towns having a population more than 10,000: The scheme can be implemented in towns with a population more than 10,000.

questions.text: School health program is under
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - PHC (Primary Health Centre):

  • School health programs are typically under the purview of Primary Health Centres. PHCs are the most basic units of the public health system in many countries and they focus on providing primary healthcare services to the community. School health programs fall within their scope as they address the health needs of school-age children, ensuring their well-being and promoting healthy habits.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - CHC (Community Health Centre): CHCs are a step above PHCs and offer more comprehensive healthcare services to a larger catchment area.

Option C - DH (District Hospital):While they might have a role in coordinating and overseeing certain public health initiatives, school health programs are usually implemented at a more grassroots level.

Option D - Health and Wellness Centres: While they promote a comprehensive approach to healthcare, school health programs might not always be directly managed by these centers

questions.text: What is the name of the recently introduced online software by the Indian government, as part of the national tuberculosis elimination program (NTEP), for the purpose of monitoring patients with tuberculosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option  A - NIKSHAY:

  • This is the correct answer. NIKSHAY is an online software specifically designed for the National Tuberculosis Elimination Program in India. It facilitates the tracking of TB patients, monitors their treatment progress, manages drug supply, and provides real-time data for better decision-making and planning.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - NISCHAY: NISCHAY is not associated with the National Tuberculosis Elimination Program or TB patient monitoring. 

Option C - E-DOTS: While e-DOTS is a term associated with the use of electronic DOTS for TB treatment, it is not the specific software launched under the National Tuberculosis Elimination Program in India.

Option D - NIKUSTH: NIKUSTH is not a recognized software or system related to the monitoring of TB patients under the National Tuberculosis Elimination Program.

questions.text: As per IMNCI guidelines, a diagnosis of pneumonia is made in a 6-month-old infant when the child exhibits rapid breathing with a respiratory rate exceeding:
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - 50:

  • Option D. 50 breaths per minute: A 6-month-old child is said to have pneumonia if the child has fast breathing with a respiratory rate more than 50 breaths per minute.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Option A, B & C are incorrect

questions.text: Which of the following criteria would you utilize to evaluate the effectiveness of the malaria surveillance system implemented by the National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B:

  • Annual Blood Examination Rate (ABER): The ABER is the percentage of the population at risk of malaria who have undergone blood examination for malaria parasites. It indicates the coverage of the population undergoing diagnostic testing for malaria and is used to assess the efficiency of the surveillance system.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Annual Parasite Index (API): The API is used to measure the incidence or burden of malaria in a population.

Option C - Slide Positivity Rate (SPR): The SPR provides information about the proportion of individuals tested who have confirmed malaria infection.

Option D - Slide Falciparum Rate (SFR): The SFR specifically focuses on the prevalence of P. falciparum infection among tested individuals.

questions.text: Under Vision 2020, a disease that was added later in India
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Glaucoma:

  • Vision 2020: The Right to Sight is a global initiative launched by the World Health Organization (WHO) and the International Agency for the Prevention of Blindness (IAPB) to eliminate avoidable blindness by the year 2020.
  • While glaucoma is a significant cause of blindness globally, it was added later in India's Vision 2020 initiative. This highlights the growing recognition of the importance of early detection, diagnosis, and treatment of glaucoma to prevent vision loss.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Cataract: Cataract has been a significant focus of Vision 2020 from the beginning. Cataract is the leading cause of blindness worldwide, including in India. 

Option B - Childhood blindness: Childhood blindness has also been an important focus of Vision 2020.

Option D - Diabetic Retinopathy: Diabetic retinopathy is another eye condition that has been a focus of the Vision 2020 program.

questions.text: NITI AAYOG represents?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - National Institute for Transforming India: 

  • NITI Aayog (National Institution for Transforming India) is a policy Think Tank of the Government of India. It was established in 2015 to replace the Planning Commission and provide strategic and policy inputs across various sectors of the economy. NITI Aayog's main objective is to foster sustainable development and facilitate cooperative federalism by promoting the involvement of states in the economic decision-making process.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Newer Initiative Transforming India: NITI Aayog is not specifically focused on newer initiatives but rather on transforming India as a whole.

Option B - Nutrition Intake to India: NITI Aayog's mandate extends beyond nutrition intake and encompasses a broader range of policy areas.

Option D - National Institute for Technical India: NITI Aayog is not solely focused on nutrition or functioning as an institute dedicated to nutrition in India.

questions.text: Which government program aims to provide health checkups and services for children aged 0-18, including a focus on those not attending school?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakaram:

  • Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram (RBSK) involves screening of children from birth to 18 years of age for 4 Ds- Defects at birth, Diseases, Deficiencies and Development delays, spanning 32 common health conditions for early detection and free treatment and management, including surgeries at tertiary level

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Janani Suraksha Yojna: Janani Suraksha Yojana (JSY) is a government program that focuses on promoting institutional deliveries by providing financial assistance to pregnant women.

Option C - Navjaat Shishu Suraksha Karyakaram: Navjaat Shishu Suraksha Karyakaram (NSSK) is another program that aims to provide care to newborns and ensure their survival during the first 28 days of life.

Option D - Mid day meal program: The Mid Day Meal Program is a school-based initiative that provides nutritious meals to schoolchildren to enhance their nutritional status and encourage school attendance.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of Urban health care delivery system?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Subcenter:

  • In the context of the healthcare delivery system in urban areas, a subcenter is not a part of it. Subcenters are primarily a component of rural healthcare infrastructure. They are the first level of contact between the rural population and the medical officer, providing essential healthcare services at the grassroots level.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - PHC (Primary Health Center): These are health facilities designed to provide basic healthcare services to the population in urban as well as rural areas..

Option B - CHC (Community Health Center): CHCs are higher-level health facilities that are responsible for providing comprehensive healthcare services to a larger population, typically covering a group of PHCs.

Option C - Swasthya chowki: Swasthya chowki is a part of the urban health care system at the primary level.

questions.text: A 10-year-old school-going girl came for a health checkup. Her Hb is 9 g/dL. Which of the following government programs is likely to provide significant benefit to her health?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram:

  • Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram (RBSK) is a key government initiative in India focusing on children's health (0-18 years). It conducts health screenings at schools and anganwadi centers to detect issues like anemia, malnutrition, and developmental delays early. The program offers interventions, referrals, and health education to ensure children receive timely care and support, promoting their overall well-being.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Janani Suraksha Yojana: It is a program that focuses on promoting institutional deliveries and providing financial assistance to pregnant women for giving birth in health facilities.

Option C - Pradhan Mantri Matru Vandana Yojana: PMMVY is a maternity benefit program providing partial compensation for the wage loss in terms of cash incentives so that the pregnant woman can take adequate rest before and after delivery. It targets pregnant and lactating mothers, not school-aged children.

Option D - Navjat Shishu Karyakram Yojna: (Newborn and Child Health Program) focuses on the health and well-being of newborns and infants. It includes services like immunization, growth monitoring, and counseling for mothers. While it's relevant for young children, it may not directly address the presented situation of a 10-year-old girl with low hemoglobin levels.

questions.text: In the context of a national public health initiative aimed at addressing anemia, which of the following program follows the "6x6x6 strategy"?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Anemia Mukt Bharat:

  • he "6x6x6 strategy" is associated with the Anemia Mukt Bharat (AMB) initiative. This initiative is a national public health program in India aimed at combating anemia. The "6x6x6 strategy" focuses on six interventions in six target beneficiary groups over six years to reduce anemia prevalence by three percentage points per year.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Poshan Abhiyan (National Nutrition Mission): It is a multi-ministerial convergence mission that aims to address malnutrition, including anemia,. While it addresses anemia, it does not specifically follow the "6x6x6 strategy."

Option C - Kishori Shakti Yojana: It addresses various issues faced by adolescent girls but does not directly relate to the "6x6x6 strategy."
